webTitle: Cost of living: an interest rate rise could turn up the political heat

fields.standfirst: For the past few years the political fight over the cost of living has been focused on power prices and the carbon tax, but if the Reserve Bank decides to lift rates it will have a far greater impact
fields.body:
Cost of living is always a hot-button political issue. Figures released last week revealed that the annual growth of cost of living for all households slowed over the past three months, largely due to the end of the carbon price in June. While the increase in cost of living for all households is generally lower than usual, the lack of interest rate changes over the past year, however, means that for the first time since 2012 the rise in cost of living is the same for employee households as it is for age pensioner households. It is a reminder that interest rates don’t always go down, and when they start to go up, cost of living becomes even more politically hot than usual.

The cost of living index differs somewhat from the standard inflation measure of the consumer price index (CPI). The CPI is an average for all households in Australia and it includes housing prices but not interest payments. The cost of living index on the other hand splits households into different types (employees, age pensioners, self-funded retirees, and other government benefit recipients). The cost of living index also measures interest payments, but not housing prices.

This difference explains why the cost of living for all household types rose in the past year by less than did the CPI. Housing prices have certainly been rising, but mortgage payments have not – as the RBA has not changed interest rates since August last year.

Thus while the CPI rose by 2.3% over the past year, the cost of living for employee and age pensioner households increased by just 1.9%:

The households which saw the cost of living rise the most in the past year were those whose main earner received government benefits. The cost of living for these households increased by the same amount as the CPI, at a rate of 2.3%.

The difference between the CPI and the cost of living for pensioners and those on government benefits is important because the government in the May budget changed the indexation arrangements for pensions and other benefits from 2017 to be set by just the CPI rather than higher rates of either average weekly earnings or the cost of living for pensioner and benefits households.

As a general rule, the CPI rises slower than the cost of living index for pensioners and households on benefits. Thus raising the pension and other welfare benefits by less than it otherwise would have, the government ends up saving money in the long run.

However, in the past 12 months the CPI has risen 0.2% points faster than the cost of living index so, were this to occur again in 2017, pensioners and households would be no worse off than previously (assuming average weekly earnings did not rise by more than either the cost of living or CPI).

The figures also show that the overall advantage of lower costs of living increases for employee households compared to all other households is declining as they become more likely to be paying off a mortgage than renting.

Employee households on average spend 11.7% of their weekly expenses on interest payments. These can include credit cards, but overwhelmingly it is mortgage payments.

By contrast, households whose main income is government benefits spend just 4.9% on interest payments. But even that towers above the mere 0.91% spent by aged pensioner households and 0.7% spent by self-funded retirees on interest. It is not that aged pensioners or retirees are renting to any great extent, but that many have paid off their mortgage already.

The drop in electricity prices due to the end of the carbon price also benefitted pensioners and welfare households as they spend a greater share of their weekly expenditure on power than employee households.

Non-mortgage households, however, have missed out on enjoying the substantial decline in interest payments that have occurred over the past two years since the RBA began cutting interest rates:

As interest rates have not moved for 13 months – and is unlikely to change tomorrow either – the decrease in mortgage holders’ cost of living from these low interest payments has mostly come to an end.

The cost of living index also highlights, as I discussed last week, how moves to include fresh food under the GST would affect different households.

As a general rule, aged pensioners and welfare dependent households spend more of their weekly expenditure on food than employee households. Employee households on average spend just 16.9% of their weekly expenditure on food and non-alcoholic drinks.

By comparison, aged pensioner households spend 22.4% and other welfare dependent households spend 19.3%.

But more importantly given it is currently GST free, pensioners and welfare dependent households spend more of their money on fresh food, whereas employee households spend 34% of their weekly food budget eating out – ether on take-away or at restaurants – which is already subject to GST.

Aged pensioners spend just 3.3% of their weekly expenditure eating out (equivalent to about 15% of their weekly food budget).

Thus, changes to the GST that would tax food will disproportionately impact aged pensioner households more than employee households. And the poorer the household, regardless of whether they are employed or not, the more income, and therefore tax, would be spent on food.

However, some rise in cost of living is more about choice than necessity. While there is always an aspect of keeping up with the Joneses in all households expenditure, if anyone would wish to reduce their cost of living increase, the first thing they should do is quit smoking.

Households dependent upon welfare are far and away the biggest consumers of tobacco products:

Nearly 6% of such households’ weekly expenditure is on tobacco. In September 2011 the ABS calculated this at around $45 a week. However, given tobacco prices have risen 33% in that time (compared to 6.6% for inflation as a whole) that would mean such households would now be spending around $60 a week.

The $60 a week amount is an average that includes households who don’t smoke. Given a 25 pack of cigarettes can now easily set you back $20-$25, you wouldn’t even need to smoke a pack a day to be forking out over $100 a week.

Cost of living increases are ever present for every household, but for the past two years the weak economy has kept down price rises. The end of the carbon price has also seen another reduction in cost of living increases. The period of RBA interest rate cuts also greatly helped mortgage holding households reduce their cost of living, compared to other households. But the lack of cuts since August last year means that benefit is an end.

For the past two to three years the political cost of living fight has been over power prices and carbon taxes. This is somewhat unusual as while power prices are always contentious, mortgage payments are usually the main source of cost of living pain – both for households and governments. The RBA currently seems comfortable with where rates are. Should it decide next year to start increasing them, expect the cries from mortgage holders about cost of living will be loudly directed at the government – and the end of the carbon tax will by then be long forgotten.

However, in the past 12 months the CPI has risen 0.2% points faster than the cost of living index so, were this to occur again in 2017, pensioners and households would be no worse off than previously (assuming average weekly earnings did not rise by more than either the cost of living or CPI). The figures also show that the overall advantage of lower costs of living increases for employee households compared to all other households is declining as they become more likely to be paying off a mortgage than renting. Employee households on average spend 11.7% of their weekly expenses on interest payments. These can include credit cards, but overwhelmingly it is mortgage payments. By contrast, households whose main income is government benefits spend just 4.9% on interest payments. But even that towers above the mere 0.91% spent by aged pensioner households and 0.7% spent by self-funded retirees on interest. It is not that aged pensioners or retirees are renting to any great extent, but that many have paid off their mortgage already. The drop in electricity prices due to the end of the carbon price also benefitted pensioners and welfare households as they spend a greater share of their weekly expenditure on power than employee households. Non-mortgage households, however, have missed out on enjoying the substantial decline in interest payments that have occurred over the past two years since the RBA began cutting interest rates: As interest rates have not moved for 13 months – and is unlikely to change tomorrow either – the decrease in mortgage holders’ cost of living from these low interest payments has mostly come to an end. The cost of living index also highlights, as I discussed last week, how moves to include fresh food under the GST would affect different households. As a general rule, aged pensioners and welfare dependent households spend more of their weekly expenditure on food than employee households. Employee households on average spend just 16.9% of their weekly expenditure on food and non-alcoholic drinks. By comparison, aged pensioner households spend 22.4% and other welfare dependent households spend 19.3%. But more importantly given it is currently GST free, pensioners and welfare dependent households spend more of their money on fresh food, whereas employee households spend 34% of their weekly food budget eating out – ether on take-away or at restaurants – which is already subject to GST. Aged pensioners spend just 3.3% of their weekly expenditure eating out (equivalent to about 15% of their weekly food budget). Thus, changes to the GST that would tax food will disproportionately impact aged pensioner households more than employee households. And the poorer the household, regardless of whether they are employed or not, the more income, and therefore tax, would be spent on food. However, some rise in cost of living is more about choice than necessity. While there is always an aspect of keeping up with the Joneses in all households expenditure, if anyone would wish to reduce their cost of living increase, the first thing they should do is quit smoking. Households dependent upon welfare are far and away the biggest consumers of tobacco products: Nearly 6% of such households’ weekly expenditure is on tobacco. In September 2011 the ABS calculated this at around $45 a week. However, given tobacco prices have risen 33% in that time (compared to 6.6% for inflation as a whole) that would mean such households would now be spending around $60 a week. The $60 a week amount is an average that includes households who don’t smoke. Given a 25 pack of cigarettes can now easily set you back $20-$25, you wouldn’t even need to smoke a pack a day to be forking out over $100 a week. Cost of living increases are ever present for every household, but for the past two years the weak economy has kept down price rises. The end of the carbon price has also seen another reduction in cost of living increases. The period of RBA interest rate cuts also greatly helped mortgage holding households reduce their cost of living, compared to other households. But the lack of cuts since August last year means that benefit is an end. For the past two to three years the political cost of living fight has been over power prices and carbon taxes. This is somewhat unusual as while power prices are always contentious, mortgage payments are usually the main source of cost of living pain – both for households and governments. The RBA currently seems comfortable with where rates are. Should it decide next year to start increasing them, expect the cries from mortgage holders about cost of living will be loudly directed at the government – and the end of the carbon tax will by then be long forgotten.
fields.headline: Cost of living: an interest rate rise could turn up the political heat
fields.trailText: For the past few years the political fight over the cost of living has been focused on power prices and the carbon tax, but if the Reserve Bank decides to lift rates it will have a far greater impact, writes Greg Jericho

webTitle: CBI: UK is ducking infrastructure decisions

fields.bodyText: Politicians are compromising British progress by failing to tackle the difficult decisions on long-term infrastructure, the CBI has warned. The business lobby group said progress had been marred by a “two steps forward and three steps back” approach for far too long. An overwhelming majority – 96% – of business leaders surveyed by the CBI said political uncertainty was discouraging investment. The UK’s infrastructure network is internationally weak, lagging behind North America, the EU, and Australasia according to respondents to the CBI/URS infrastructure survey: 61% of business leaders consider infrastructure in other EU countries to be better than the UK’s - an increase from 59% in 2011. Katja Hall, CBI deputy director-general, said there was a need for politicians to make decisions on infrastructure that extend beyond the five-year electoral cycle. “Politicians are too often seen as ducking the big, politically difficult questions looming large on businesses’ risk register, like runway capacity and long-term road funding, rather than grasping the nettle. “We’re at a crossroads. The next government must build on the successful policies of this parliament, but we also need to see bold thinking and a renewal of the politics of infrastructure, finding a new way to agree upon and then consistently deliver the improvements we’ll need over the next fifty years – not just the next five.” Hall said that the majority of businesses backed the creation of an independent body to assess Britain’s long-term infrastructure needs, lifting the political barriers to progress. “That 99% of firms think this would have helped the government make a more compelling case for HS2 demonstrates the powerful role a more independent voice could play,” she said. Optimism about the outlook was weak, with 77% of those surveyed predicting Britain’s motorways will stay the same or get worse in the next five years. Meanwhile 46% of firms in London said that the UK’s indecision on new runway capacity was already impacting investment decisions. In a separate report, the manufacturing trade body EEF urged the government to “finish the job” on Britain’s roads by boosting investment in the UK’s crumbling network. EEF members felt the quality of Britain’s infrastructure was declining rather than improving. “Roads are the backbone of the economy and the glue that holds the rest of the transport network together, with four-fifths of manufacturers saying they are critical to their business operations,” said Terry Scuoler, EEF chief executive. “The message from manufacturers to the chancellor for the remainder of this parliament is clear, complete the job on vital roads, energy and broadband projects. As far as industry is concerned these are far more important than redirecting planning resources to new aspirational projects.”
